{% raw %}

Encoder¶

class Encoder[source]

Encoder(awd_lstm:AWD_LSTM, out_size:int) :: Module

Base class for all neural network modules.

Your models should also subclass this class.

Modules can also contain other Modules, allowing to nest them in a tree structure. You can assign the submodules as regular attributes::

import torch.nn as nn
import torch.nn.functional as F

class Model(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self):
        super(Model, self).__init__()
        self.conv1 = nn.Conv2d(1, 20, 5)
        self.conv2 = nn.Conv2d(20, 20, 5)

    def forward(self, x):
        x = F.relu(self.conv1(x))
        return F.relu(self.conv2(x))

Submodules assigned in this way will be registered, and will have their parameters converted too when you call :meth:to, etc.

awd_lstm = AWD_LSTM(vocab_sz=8472, emb_sz=400, n_hid=1152, n_layers=3)
encoder = Encoder(awd_lstm, 100)
inp_ids = torch.randint(0, 100, (16, 20))
last_hid = encoder(inp_ids)
test_eq(last_hid.shape, (16, 100))

# skip
encoder = Encoder.from_pretrained(Path('./coco_small/awd_lstm-1.pt'), Path('./coco_small/vocab.json'), 100)
inp_ids = torch.randint(0, 100, (16, 20))
last_hid = encoder(inp_ids)
test_eq(last_hid.shape, (16, 100))

Decoder¶

class Decoder[source]

Decoder(out_size:int, inp_size:int, num_layers=3) :: Module

Base class for all neural network modules.

Your models should also subclass this class.

Modules can also contain other Modules, allowing to nest them in a tree structure. You can assign the submodules as regular attributes::

import torch.nn as nn
import torch.nn.functional as F

class Model(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self):
        super(Model, self).__init__()
        self.conv1 = nn.Conv2d(1, 20, 5)
        self.conv2 = nn.Conv2d(20, 20, 5)

    def forward(self, x):
        x = F.relu(self.conv1(x))
        return F.relu(self.conv2(x))

Submodules assigned in this way will be registered, and will have their parameters converted too when you call :meth:to, etc.

decoder = Decoder(64, 100)
enc_last_hid = torch.randn(16, 100)
out = decoder(enc_last_hid)
test_eq(out.shape, (16, 3, 64, 64))
decoder.summary(enc_last_hid)

decoder2 = Decoder(96, 100)
decoder2.load_state_dict(decoder.state_dict())
enc_last_hid = torch.randn(16, 100)
out = decoder2(enc_last_hid)
test_eq(out.shape, (16, 3, 96, 96))
decoder2.summary(enc_last_hid)

decoder2.change_out_size(128)
enc_last_hid = torch.randn(16, 100)
out = decoder2(enc_last_hid)
test_eq(out.shape, (16, 3, 128, 128))
decoder2.summary(enc_last_hid)

Generator¶

class Seq2Seq[source]

Seq2Seq(encoder:Encoder, decoder:Decoder) :: Module

Base class for all neural network modules.

Your models should also subclass this class.

Modules can also contain other Modules, allowing to nest them in a tree structure. You can assign the submodules as regular attributes::

import torch.nn as nn
import torch.nn.functional as F

class Model(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self):
        super(Model, self).__init__()
        self.conv1 = nn.Conv2d(1, 20, 5)
        self.conv2 = nn.Conv2d(20, 20, 5)

    def forward(self, x):
        x = F.relu(self.conv1(x))
        return F.relu(self.conv2(x))

Submodules assigned in this way will be registered, and will have their parameters converted too when you call :meth:to, etc.

seq2seq = Seq2Seq(encoder, decoder)
inp_ids = torch.randint(0, 100, (16, 20))
out = seq2seq(inp_ids)
test_eq(out.shape, (16, 3, 64, 64))

get_generator[source]

get_generator(awd_lstm_path:Path, vocab_path:Path, enc_out_size:int, dec_out_size:int, num_dec_layers:int=3)

# skip
generator = get_generator(Path('./coco_small/awd_lstm-1.pt'), Path('./coco_small/vocab.json'), 100, 64)
inp_ids = torch.randint(0, 100, (16, 20))
out = generator(inp_ids)
test_eq(out.shape, (16, 3, 64, 64))

generator.decoder.change_out_size(96)
out = generator(inp_ids)
test_eq(out.shape, (16, 3, 96, 96))
